answers: The Wretched of the Earth [Les Damnés de la Terre]
family [accept nuclear family; prompt on marriage]
parts: Name this process whose "settler" form is when people emigrate with the goal of creating a society to replace that of indigenous people. Anti-imperialists like Diderot criticized European use of this process in the East Indies.

This work of anti-colonial philosophy discusses how violence by colonized workers and the lumpenproletariat is crucial to destabilize the social order created by colonizers and colonized intellectuals.

The Wretched of the Earth is by Frantz Fanon, who also wrote about how the "Algerian" variety of this institution relies on rigid roles. Some queer theorists reject this institution's "nuclear" type as heteronormative.

answers: vitamin D [accept vitamin D2 or vitamin D3]
ultraviolet light [or ultraviolet radiation or UV light or UV radiation or UVB light or UVB radiation]
parts: Name this vitamin whose deficiency causes rickets. Calcitriol ("CAL-si-tree-awl") is this vitamin's active form.
Vitamin D3 is often synthesized when 7-dehydrocholesterol reacts with the B form of this radiation. Exposure to this form of radiation during sunbathing may cause DNA damage and cancer.
This hormone upregulates vitamin D production in the kidney. This hormone increases calcium levels in the blood and is produced by chief cells.
Name this fruit. Andy Warhol included a "peelable" one of these yellow fruits on his cover art for the album Velvet Underground & Nico.

Bananas and a statue are present in the foreground of this metaphysical artist's paintings The Uncertainty of the Poet and The Transformed Dream. This artist also painted The Mystery and Melancholy of a Street.
One of these things appears behind a brick wall in The Uncertainty of the Poet. The hazy figure of one of these things approaches a bridge with a rabbit in a J.M.W. Turner painting.

answers: World War I [or WWI; or the Great War]
Tanzania [United Republic of Tanzania; or Jamhuri ya Muungano wa Tanzania]
parts: Name this war where Paul von Lettow-Worbeck's Askari and Ruga-Ruga fighters harassed a much larger force led by Jan ("YON") Smuts during its East African campaign.

Lettow-Worbeck's force primarily operated in this present-day country, which became a British colony after the war. This country was later led by Julius Nyerere after its independence from British rule.

The German forces in the East African Campaign were dealt a blow in morale when one of these dirigibles carrying supplies failed to reach them. The Hindenburg was one of these giant balloon-like crafts.

answers: James Joyce [or James Augustine Aloysius Joyce]
parts: Name this setting of "A Little Cloud." In a different work set in this city, a boy visits a bazaar to buy something for Mangan's sister but is unable to get anything because he arrived too late.
"A Little Cloud" and "Araby" are stories that appear in Dubliners, a short story collection written by this Irish author of A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man and Ulysses.
After leaving a Christmas party in this final story of Dubliners, Gabriel Conroy's wife tells him about Michael Furey, a boy she used to love as a teenager who passed away at the age of 17.

answers: iodine [or I; accept triiodide or iodine-starch complex]
parts: Name this lab technique. In the acid-base type of this lab technique, the endpoint is marked by the color change of a pH sensitive indicator.
One common method of titration is named for this element. The ability of an anion of this halogen to form a deeply-colored complex with starch is useful in marking the endpoint of titrations.
In an iodometric titration, sources of this anion are commonly used as a reducing agent to generate iodide. This anion has chemical formula S2O3 2- ("S two O three, two minus").

answers: Sweden [or Kingdom of Sweden; or Konungariket Sverige]
parts: Name this director of The Strange Thing About the Johnsons. A film by this director ends with the protagonist smiling through tears as Christian is burned to death in a triangular temple while inside the skin of a disemboweled bear.
Aster's film Midsommar is mostly set in a commune in this country during a midsummer celebration. The director of The Seventh Seal, Ingmar Bergman, was from this Scandinavian country.

Midsommar includes several tilts away from the characters toward this object to emphasize its role in their degradation. Akira Kurosawa's Rashomon was one of the first films to include shots pointing at this object.

answers: Roman Empire [or Rome; or Imperium Rōmānum; or Basileía tôn Rhōmaíōn]

immigrating to Israel [accept any answer indicating people returning to Israel; prompt on answers about Zionism; or the founding of Israel; or obtaining Israeli citizenship; prompt on evacuation; prompt on ascent or the act of going up]
parts: Name this modern-day country whose Jewish population can be traced back to the kingdom of Himyar. The earlier kingdom of Saba' in this country exported frankincense and myrrh.

Many Jews immigrated to Himyar from this empire's province of Judea after the Bar Kokhba revolt. This empire's ruler Augustus Caesar, ordered an expedition to Yemen, which was known in this empire as Arabia Felix.

Description acceptable. In the 20th century, Operation Magic Carpet assisted Yemenite Jews with performing this action, known in Hebrew as "aliyah." The Law of Return gives Jewish people the right to perform this action.
Name this politician, who finished fourth in that mayoral primary. This proponent of universal basic income earlier gained fame during his 2020 run for president.
Eric Adams is seeking to be mayor of this city currently led by Bill DeBlasio. During 9/11, this city was led by Rudy Giuliani.

In addition to ranked choice voting, New York elections use this system where a candidate can be nominated by multiple parties. As a result of this system, the Working Families Party endorsed Democrat Maya Wiley for mayor.
Name this poem whose second section revolves around a journey up a mountain with seven terraces that culminates with the narrator meeting Beatrice who becomes his guide.
This poet coined the term for Dolce Stil Novo, or "sweet new style," in Purgatorio, which follows Inferno as part of his epic poem The Divine Comedy.
Dolce Stil Novo has its roots in poetry written in this language. In Purgatorio, Dante sees Arnaut Daniel, a troubadour who is credited with inventing the sestina in this language.
Name this politician and member of the Great Triumvirate of early 19th-century U.S. politics who served as Vice President under John Quincy Adams and Andrew Jackson.

Calhoun was from this state, and after resigning as Jackson's Vice President, penned its namesake Exposition and Protest during the Nullification Crisis. The Civil War began with the shelling of Fort Sumter in this state.

Under John Tyler and James K. Polk, Calhoun served a stint in this cabinet post after the death of his predecessor Abel P. Upshur. A later holder of this post was the target of an assassination attempt by Lewis Powell.
Stokes' theorem relates the surface integral of this operator applied to a vector field to the line integral of that vector field. This operator is written as "del cross."
Stokes' theorem can be reduced to Green's theorem for a curve that can be embedded into a plane with this many dimensions. The Cartesian plane has this many dimensions, as it has no z-axis.

The generalized Stokes theorem is a statement about the integration of different forms on these objects, which are topological spaces that locally resemble Euclidean ("yoo-KLI-dee-un") space near each point.

This grandmaster defeated Boris Spassky at the 1972 World Chess Championship in Reykjavik ["RAKE-ya-vick"]. He would not play another public game until 1992, and became notorious for his intensely antisemitic views.
In the 2018 World Chess Championship, Magnus Carlsen used this opening every time he was on black. In this defense, black responds to white playing a pawn to e4 by moving their own pawn to c5.

The majority of Carlsen's Sicilian Defenses were the Sveshnikov variation, in which this piece moves to e5 on black’s fifth move. Each side has eight of these pieces, which move forward and capture diagonally.

answers: poker [prompt on playing cards or gambling]
Tennessee Williams [or Thomas Lanier Williams III]
parts: Name this activity that Mitch says "shouldn't be played in a house with women" after a man starts beating his wife for calling him a "drunk animal thing."
Soon after beating his wife for interrupting his poker game in this play, Stanley slightly sobers up and sees that his wife left the house, causing him to run out the front door and scream, "Stella!"
A Streetcar Named Desire was written by this American playwright of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.

answers: Útgarða-Loki [or Utgarda-Loki or Utgardsloki; accept Skrýmir]
parts: Name this giant who then revealed that the contests had been rigged all along before vanishing with his castle into midair.

During a drinking contest, Thor failed to drain his mead horn. Útgarða-Loki ("OOT-guard-LOW-key") revealed that the horn had actually been connected to this general location, and Thor's gigantic gulps had caused the tides.
Although he claimed that he can eat faster than anyone, Loki lost an eating competition to a being named Logi, who turned out to be the personification of this substance.

answers: precession [accept Larmor precession or Lense-Thirring precession]
acceleration [prompt on a, accept centripetal acceleration, do not accept "angular acceleration"]
parts: Larmor names a form of this phenomenon, which is a change in the first Euler angle. The Lense-Thirring form of this effect is caused by relativistic frame-dragging.
The Larmor formula, which calculates the amount of power from a point charge, includes a term for the "proper" form of this quantity. One form of this quantity is calculated as v squared over r.
Larmor also studied periodicity in "dark spots" on this object, which is orbited by the Earth in Copernican heliocentrism.

answers: Béla Bartók [or Béla Viktor János Bartók]
parts: Name this four-stringed instrument slightly larger than a violin. Players of this instrument use alto clef.
This composer wrote a viola concerto for Lionel Tertis. This English composer of the coronation march Crown Imperial also wrote the cantata Belshazzar's Feast.
After this composer's death from leukemia, his viola concerto was completed by his son Peter. This Hungarian composer included a "Game of Pairs" section in his Concerto for Orchestra.

answers: humanity [accept equivalents like being human or answers indicating that he had both human and divine aspects]
Nicene Creed [or Symbolum Nicaenum or Council of Nicaea]
parts: This Oriental Orthodox Church regards St. Mark as their first patriarch. A verse beginning "Sing to the Lord a new song" begins this church's Feast of the Martyrs, or El-Nayrouz.

Opponents of the Oriental Orthodox accuse them of following monophysitism, which denies this aspect of Christ. People arguing that Christ had this trait often point to John's pronouncement that "the Word became flesh."

Oriental Orthodoxy shares this creed with the Eastern Orthodox and Catholic Churches. This creed, which affirms the trinity and Jesus' humanity, is named after the first ever ecumenical council, which Constantine called.

answers: South Korea [or Republic of Korea; prompt on Korea, do not accept or prompt on "North Korea"]
Yasunari Kawabata [accept names in either order] (The second novel is Snow Country.)
parts: Name this country home to the author of The Vegetarian. Another author from this country wrote a novel in second-person about a family's search for their mother after she is lost in a subway station, Please Look After Mom.

In The Vegetarian, a character fantasizes about Yeong-hye's birthmark which is shaped like one of these objects. In Kim Sowol's poem "Azaleas," the speaker picks these objects from Mount Yak and scatters them on the ground.

A novel by this author begins with Kikuji recalling his experience of seeing a woman's birthmark on her breast. In addition to Thousand Cranes, this author wrote about Shimamura's affair with Komako in another novel.
The Lex Oppia banned women from wearing lavish clothing of this color. This color was widely seen as a symbol of nobility and its dye was collected from the murex sea snail in ancient times.
One important religious position held exclusively by women was this group of female priests. They were held to be incorruptible, and tended to the sacred fire of the goddess of the hearth.
This powerful woman was given the rights of the Vestal Virgins, despite not being one herself. This wife of Claudius was most likely assassinated on the orders of her son Nero.
